body_content.explanation: to move your hand or an object onto the surface of something so that it touches it, usually with force:
examples: Teachers are not allowed to hit their pupils.
This type of glass won't shatter no matter how hard you hit it.
She hit her thumb with the hammer.

body_content.explanation: to touch something with sudden force:
examples: They were going about 60 kilometres an hour when their car hit the tree.
One journalist was hit in the leg by a stray bullet.
That new shelf in the bathroom is too low - I just hit my head on it.

body_content.explanation: to have an unpleasant or negative effect on a person or thing:
examples: Production has been badly hit by the strike.
Demand for transatlantic flights has been hit by fears of terrorist attacks.

body_content.explanation: If an idea or thought hits you, you suddenly think of it:
examples: That's when it hit me that my life would never be the same again.

body_content.explanation: to shoot at or bomb a place or person, causing damage or injury:
examples: Two schools were hit during the air raid.
He was hit in the neck by a bullet from a sniper.
Try to hit the middle of the target.

body_content.explanation: to arrive at a place or position:
examples: If we turn left at the next junction, we should hit the main road after five miles or so.

body_content.explanation: to succeed in reaching or achieving something:
examples: Our profits hit an all-time high of $20 million last year.
I just can't hit (= sing) those high notes like I used to.

body_content.explanation: to like someone and become friendly immediately:
examples: I didn't really hit it off with his friends.
Three drug dealers were hit in the city over the weekend.
Walsh hit 10 fours and two sixes in his fourth one-day century.
Yesterday, he faced 74 balls and hit nine fours and two sixes.

body_content.explanation: in baseball, to hit the ball with a particular result :
examples: He hit a career-high 17 home runs last year.
In her first at bat, she hit a single.

body_content.explanation: in baseball, to have a particular batting average (= a number that represents how often a player successfully hits the ball compared to the number of times they have a chance to hit the ball):
examples: He hit .372 with 6 home runs, 14 RBIs, and 15 runs scored.

body_content.explanation: a thing or person that is very popular or successful:
examples: The Beatles had a string of number-one hits in the 1960s.
Your cake was a real hit at the party - everyone commented.
They've just released an album of their greatest hits (= their most successful songs).

body_content.explanation: a request to use a web page on the internet that is then counted to calculate the number of people looking at the page:
examples: Our page had 243 hits this week.

body_content.explanation: the act of hitting something or someone, or an occasion when something or someone hits you:
examples: She gave him a hit on the head which knocked him flying.

body_content.explanation: in baseball, when the batter (= person trying to hit the ball) safely reaches first base after hitting the ball
an occasion when something that has been thrown, dropped, shot, etc. at a place or object reaches that place or object:
examples: The rebel headquarters took a direct hit from a bomb during the attack.
I scored a hit on my second shot.
He was the victim of a mafia hit.
